Complete the following Lean 4 code:
```lean4
import Mathlib

open Matrix Filter Topology Set Nat

/--
Consider the system of differential equations $$\frac{dx}{dt} = -2y + u(t), \frac{dy}{dt} = -2x + u(t)$$ for some continuous function $u(t)$. Prove that, if $x(0) \ne y(0)$, the solution will never pass through $(0, 0)$ regardless of the choice of $u(t)$, and if $x(0) = y(0)$, a suitable $u(t)$ can be chosen for any $T > 0$ so that $(x(T), y(T)) = (0, 0)$.
-/
theorem putnam_1969_a5
    (x0 y0 t : ℝ)
    (ht : 0 < t) :
    x0 = y0 ↔ ∃ x y u : ℝ → ℝ,
      Differentiable ℝ x ∧
      Differentiable ℝ y ∧
      Continuous u ∧
      deriv x = - 2 • y + u ∧
      deriv y = - 2 • x + u ∧
      x 0 = x0 ∧
      y 0 = y0 ∧
      x t = 0 ∧
      y t = 0 :=
  sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_a5
    (x0 y0 t : ℝ)
    (ht : 0 < t) :
    x0 = y0 ↔ ∃ x y u : ℝ → ℝ,
      Differentiable ℝ x ∧
      Differentiable ℝ y ∧
      Continuous u ∧
      deriv x = - 2 • y + u ∧
      deriv y = - 2 • x + u ∧
      x 0 = x0 ∧
      y 0 = y0 ∧
      x t = 0 ∧
      y t = 0 := by
  apply Iff.intro
  · -- Forward direction: If x0 = y0, then there exists a solution with (x(T), y(T)) = (0, 0)
    intro h
    use fun t => x0 * t + x0, fun t => x0 * t + y0, fun t => -2 * x0
    <;>
    (try simp_all [mul_comm])
    <;>
    (try norm_num)
    <;>
    (try ring_nf)
    <;>
    (try
      norm_num
      <;>
      linarith)
    <;>
    (try
      aesop)
  · -- Reverse direction: If there exists a solution with (x(T), y(T)) = (0, 0), then x0 = y0
    rintro ⟨x, y, u, hx, hy, hu, h1, h2, h3, h4⟩
    have h5 := congr_fun h1 0
    have h6 := congr_fun h2 0
    have h7 := congr_fun h1 t
    have h8 := congr_fun h2 t
    simp at h5 h6 h7 h8
    <;>
    (try aesop)
    <;>
    (try linarith)
    <;>
    (try simp_all [mul_comm])
    <;>
    (try ring_nf)
    <;>
    (try
      aesop)
```

theorem putnam_1969_a5
    (x0 y0 t : ℝ)
    (ht : 0 < t) :
    x0 = y0 ↔ ∃ x y u : ℝ → ℝ,
      Differentiable ℝ x ∧
      Differentiable ℝ y ∧
      Continuous u ∧
      deriv x = - 2 • y + u ∧
      deriv y = - 2 • x + u ∧
      x 0 = x0 ∧
      y 0 = y0 ∧
      x t = 0 ∧
      y t = 0 := by
  apply Iff.intro
  · intro h
    use fun s => x0 * s + x0, fun s => x0 * s + y0, fun s => -2 * x0
    <;>
    (try simp_all [mul_comm]) <;>
    (try norm_num) <;>
    (try aesop) <;>
    (try
      {
        have h1 : x0 = y0 := by aesop
        simp_all [mul_comm]
        <;>
        aesop
      })
  · rintro ⟨x, y, u, hx, hy, hu, h1, h2, h3, h4⟩
    have h5 : x0 = y0 := by
      have h6 := congr_fun h1 0
      have h7 := congr_fun h2 0
      have h8 := congr_fun h3 0
      have h9 := congr_fun h4 0
      simp at h6 h7 h8 h9
      linarith
    exact h5

-/

    (x0 y0 t : ℝ)
    (ht : 0 < t) :
    x0 = y0 ↔ ∃ x y u : ℝ → ℝ,
      Differentiable ℝ x ∧
      Differentiable ℝ y ∧
      Continuous u ∧
      deriv x = - 2 • y + u ∧

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_a5
    (x0 y0 t : ℝ)
    (ht : 0 < t) :
    x0 = y0 ↔ ∃ x y u : ℝ → ℝ,
      Differentiable ℝ x ∧
      Differentiable ℝ y ∧
      Continuous u ∧
      deriv x = - 2 • y + u ∧
      deriv y = - 2 • x + u ∧
      x 0 = x0 ∧
      y 0 = y0 ∧
      x t = 0 ∧
      y t = 0 := by
  constructor
  · intro h
    use fun t => x0 + (t / 3) * (x0 - y0)
    use fun t => y0 + (t / 3) * (x0 - y0)
    use fun t => -2 * y0 + x0
    have h₁ : Differentiable ℝ (fun t => x0 + (t / 3) * (x0 - y0)) := by
      apply Differentiable.add
      · exact differentiable_const _
      · apply Differentiable.mul
        · exact differentiable_id
        · exact differentiable_const _
    have h₂ : Differentiable ℝ (fun t => y0 + (t / 3) * (x0 - y0)) := by
      apply Differentiable.add
      · exact differentiable_const _
      · apply Differentiable.mul
        · exact differentiable_id
        · exact differentiable_const _
    have h₃ : Continuous (fun t => -2 * y0 + x0) := by
      exact continuous_const.add continuous_const
    constructor
    · funext t
      simp [h, mul_comm]
      <;> ring_nf
      <;> norm_num
      <;> linarith
    constructor
    · funext t
      simp [h, mul_comm]
      <;> ring_nf
      <;> norm_num
      <;> linarith
    constructor
    · simp [h]
    · constructor
      · simp [h]
      · constructor
        · simp [h]
        · constructor
          · simp [h]
          · constructor
            · simp [h]
            · simp [h]
  · rintro ⟨x, y, u, hx, hy, hu, h1, h2, h3, h4⟩
    have h5 : x0 = y0 := by
      have h6 := h1 0
      have h7 := h2 0
      have h8 := h3
      have h9 := h4
      simp at h6 h7 h8 h9
      <;> linarith
    exact h5
```

-/

    (x0 y0 t : ℝ)
    (ht : 0 < t) :
    x0 = y0 ↔ ∃ x y u : ℝ → ℝ,
      Differentiable ℝ x ∧
      Differentiable ℝ y ∧

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_a5
    (x0 y0 t : ℝ)
    (ht : 0 < t) :
    x0 = y0 ↔ ∃ x y u : ℝ → ℝ,
      Differentiable ℝ x ∧
      Differentiable ℝ y ∧
      Continuous u ∧
      deriv x = - 2 • y + u ∧
      deriv y = - 2 • x + u ∧
      x 0 = x0 ∧
      y 0 = y0 ∧
      x t = 0 ∧
      y t = 0 := by
  apply Iff.intro
  · -- Assume x0 = y0
    intro h
    use fun t => x0 + 0 * t, fun t => y0 + 0 * t, fun t => 2 * x0
    constructor <;> simp_all [h] <;>
    (try
      {
        have h1 : Differentiable ℝ (fun t : ℝ => x0 + 0 * t) := by
          apply differentiable_const
        have h2 : Differentiable ℝ (fun t : ℝ => y0 + 0 * t) := by
          apply differentiable_const
        simp_all [h1, h2]
      }) <;>
    (try
      {
        have h1 : Continuous (fun t : ℝ => 2 * x0) := by
          apply continuous_const
        simp_all [h1]
      }) <;>
    (try
      {
        funext t
        simp_all
      })
  · -- Assume there exist x, y, u satisfying the conditions
    rintro ⟨x, y, u, hx, hy, hu, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6⟩
    have h7 := congr_fun h1 0
    have h8 := congr_fun h2 0
    have h9 := congr_fun h1 t
    have h10 := congr_fun h2 t
    simp_all
    <;>
    (try
      {
        have h11 := hx.differentiableAt
        have h12 := hy.differentiableAt
        simp_all [deriv_const]
        <;>
        linarith
      })
    <;>
    (try
      {
        have h11 := hx.differentiableAt
        have h12 := hy.differentiableAt
        simp_all [deriv_const]
        <;>
        linarith
      })
```

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_a5
    (x0 y0 t : ℝ)
    (ht : 0 < t) :
    x0 = y0 ↔ ∃ x y u : ℝ → ℝ,
      Differentiable ℝ x ∧
      Differentiable ℝ y ∧
      Continuous u ∧
      deriv x = - 2 • y + u ∧
      deriv y = - 2 • x + u ∧
      x 0 = x0 ∧
      y 0 = y0 ∧
      x t = 0 ∧
      y t = 0 := by
  apply Iff.intro
  · -- Forward direction: If x0 = y0, then we can find x, y, u satisfying the conditions.
    intro h
    use fun t => x0 * t + x0, fun t => x0 * t + y0, fun t => -2 * x0
    have h1 : Differentiable ℝ (fun t => x0 * t + x0) := by
      apply Differentiable.add
      · apply Differentiable.mul
        · exact differentiable_const x0
        · exact differentiable_id
      · exact differentiable_const x0
    have h2 : Differentiable ℝ (fun t => x0 * t + y0) := by
      apply Differentiable.add
      · apply Differentiable.mul
        · exact differentiable_const x0
        · exact differentiable_id
      · exact differentiable_const y0
    have h3 : Continuous (fun t => -2 * x0 : ℝ → ℝ) := by
      exact continuous_const
    have h4 : deriv (fun t => x0 * t + x0) = -2 • (fun t => x0 * t + y0) + (fun t => -2 * x0) := by
      funext t
      simp [h]
      <;> ring_nf
      <;> simp_all [mul_comm]
      <;> norm_num
      <;> linarith
    have h5 : deriv (fun t => x0 * t + y0) = -2 • (fun t => x0 * t + x0) + (fun t => -2 * x0) := by
      funext t
      simp [h]
      <;> ring_nf
      <;> simp_all [mul_comm]
      <;> norm_num
      <;> linarith
    simp_all
  · -- Backward direction: If we can find x, y, u satisfying the conditions, then x0 = y0.
    rintro ⟨x, y, u, hx, hy, hu, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6⟩
    have h7 := congr_fun h1 0
    have h8 := congr_fun h2 0
    have h9 := congr_fun h1 t
    have h10 := congr_fun h2 t
    simp at h7 h8 h9 h10
    simp_all [mul_comm]
    <;> linarith
